title: 112_s3218
content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to improve coordination of export promotion programs and facilitate export opportunities for small businesses. It includes provisions for consolidating duplicative export promotion activities, clarifying roles of committee members, and enhancing Export.gov as a single window for export information. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for promoting exporting, a small business export matchmaking pilot program, export control education, an inter-agency task force on export financing, and State resource guides on Export.gov. It aims to consolidate duplicative export promotion activities and provide information about trade missions and trade fairs. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include identifying opportunities for office consolidation, coordinating electronic databases, and providing detailed listings of trade missions and fairs for better service delivery to US businesses. The Secretary of Commerce will make information on trade missions available. The Secretary of Commerce will make information on Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of departments or agencies in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying the role, goals, and objectives of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC. Additionally, it specifies the need for measuring and reporting on these goals and objectives. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of departments or agencies in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying the role, goals, and objectives of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC. Recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States related to coordination of the TPCC and its member departments and agencies are to be included. Additionally, the United States National Tourism Organization is to be replaced with the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress regarding the activities of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require annual reports to Congress by the TPCC chairperson and the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce regarding strategic plans, implementation of export promotion activities, and interagency working groups on energy. The Department of Commerce must submit an annual report to Congress by March 30 on the TPCC's performance and the successful implementation of its strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce must consult with other federal agencies' inspectors general in preparing the report. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' refers to specific committees including the Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' includes specific committees from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporters. The report will focus on making Export.gov a single website for all information required by the Federal Government for exporting articles from the United States, after consulting with small business concerns and relevant entities. Small business concerns that are exporters include the President's Export Council, State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations. SEC. 106 of the Act requires a report on creating a single website for export control compliance information. The report will assess the benefits of a comprehensive resource for exporters to comply with US export laws and regulations. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined in the section. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
- Defines terms like "Administration," "Administrator," "region of the Administration," and "small business concern."

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.
- Amends Section 22(c)(11) of the Small Business Act to include promoting exporting as a business development opportunity for small business concerns.

SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least one event will be held in each region annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program authority will end on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to improve federal export finance programs. SEC. 206 ensures the availability of state resource guides on export.gov. SEC. 206 mandates the Secretary of Commerce to provide information on export promotion and financing resources in each State on Export.gov, including details on State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
